description: Back-formation from Middle English infixed (“stuck in”), from Latin infixus, past participle of infigere (“to fasten in”).

entries.meaning: (linguistics) An affix inserted inside a root, such as -ma- in English.
(linguistics, dated) A prefix that is not at the beginning of a word, such as the con- of reconcile, or a suffix that is not at the end of a word, such as the -al of nationality.
(linguistics, proscribed) A morpheme that always appears between other morphemes in a word, such as -i- and -o- in English (i.e. an interfix).

verbs.description: infix (third-person singular simple present infixes, present participle infixing, simple past and past participle infixed)

entries.meaning: (transitive, archaic) To set; to fasten or fix by piercing or thrusting in.
examples: to infix a sting, spear, or dart

entries.meaning: (transitive, linguistics) To insert a morpheme inside an existing word.
